title: Tennis 2019: Andy Murray wins European Open, retirement, hip replacement, reaction, Stan Wawrinka
text:
Tennis: Andy Murray says he's happy to be back after winning his first ATP title since March 2017. Murray defeated Stan Wawrinka in three sets to claim the European Open title.

What a difference nine months makes.

It was early January that Murray broke down in a pre-Australian Open press conference and tearfully announced he could have played his last game.

The 31-year-old Scottish star said he’d hoped to be able to get to Wimbledon in the middle of the year — when he planned to retire — but his body let him down but not before a five-set classic.

Now nine months and a hip resurfacing surgery later, the three-time Grand Slam champion is now back in the winner’s circle, having defeated Stan Wawrinka for the European Open crown.

It’s also seen the former World No. 1 bounce back in the world rankings, rising 100 places to 127 in the world.

He is the first player to win after the hip resurfacing surgery.

Murray has said he’s a lot more optimistic about his future winning the title, which is his first ATP Tour singles title in more than two-and-a- half years.

Murray had to come back to defeat Wawrinka 3-6 6-4 6-4 in the tournament final.

Murray returned to the singles court in August, winning his first match last month in China, and the pace of his improvement has taken everyone by surprise, not least the man himself.

“I need to now start talking more about my future and I am certainly a lot more optimistic now,” he said.

The last time he lifted silverware in singles was in Dubai in March 2017, so it was understandable that the tears quickly flowed once Wawrinka’s final shot had flown well out of court.

“This is one of the biggest wins that I’ve had after everything so I’m very proud,” Murray said in his on-court interview.

It was fitting that these two men should be facing each other given it was their gruelling French Open semi-final two years ago that exacerbated physical issues for both.

Wawrinka underwent two knee operations and feared that he too might not make it back.

The 34-year-old is further down the comeback trail than Murray, but it is only this season that he has really returned to something like his old form, with his ranking dropping outside 200 last summer.

It is now back up to world No.18, while Murray’s will leap more than 100 places to 127 on Monday.

Wawrinka was the first one who could share his joy at seeing Murray back at full strength.

“I think the tennis world, including me, was really sad in Australia after that press conference,” Wawrinka said in his post-match interview.

“To see you back at this level, it’s amazing. We’re all really happy. I’m sad I lost today but I’m really happy to see you back.

“You’re an amazing champion and you deserve that. I’ve lost today but in general, it was a great week.”

But it was just the tip of the iceberg as the world rained down praise on the returning champion.

description: What a difference nine months makes.
